Award.AwardTitle: Net Ecosystem Exchange of the Lower Amazon River - from Land to the Ocean and Atmosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
River systems are becoming progressively recognized as significant components of the global carbon cycle because they modulate and adjust the carbon dynamics not only of their watersheds but also of their marine receiving waters. Their primary role is as an immense source of outgassing of CO2 from inland waters to the atmosphere. If this effect is important, then the global terrestrial CO2 sink may prove to be smaller than current estimations indicate. Unraveling the processes that occur as water travels downstream and into the ocean is critical to understanding the role of freshwater ecosystems in global C cycling, yet a mechanistic understanding of these fluxes remains elusive. Recent advances in technology allow exciting new work that has not been previously possible. Riverine systems can now be effectively examined and understood through the lenses of Net Ecosystem Exchange. The overall objective of this project is to examine the processes that govern the movement and transitions of carbon through the lower reach of the Amazon River, from Óbidos (the last traditional measuring station on the Amazon), to the ocean. An ambitious field and laboratory study, combining cutting edge geochemical and geospatial analyses, will explore the influence of downstream processing on globally-relevant geochemical fluxes.

The research itself will promote significantly greater understanding of the broader role of tropical rivers in the global carbon cycle, with the potential to shift the paradigm of how the transport and reaction of organic matter by rivers is viewed. A unique and extensive partnership with the Brazilian science community, via support from the funding agency FAPESP, will promote not only the science but significant capacity building, of both US and Brazilian students. The project team will address societal challenges in the region; as agriculture, fossil fuel exploration and hydropower demands progressively stress the lower Amazon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
TROCAS (project name, in Portuguese) directly addressed a surprising conundrum in the role of rivers in the global carbon cycle. The traditional perspective had been that rivers are simply passive pipes exporting material to the ocean, but this paradigm has shifted, with the new knowledge that rivers and other inland waters outgas immense quantities of CO2 to the atmosphere. If current estimates of net fluvial fluxes are correct, carbon cycling in rivers essentially relocates and/or mitigates almost all of the annual terrestrial carbon sequestration. But the magnitudes and underlying mechanisms that drive carbon fluxes, from land to the lower reaches of major rivers, to the oceans, remain poorly understood.  Data coverage is still sparse in remote locations such as large tropical rivers, which contribute disproportionately to CO2 outgassing compared to temperate and high-latitude systems. Most of the analyses of the fluvial carbon cycle have focused on river networks and mainstem stations “down to the last gauge,” which can be far from the ocean, especially in large rivers. Other studies have examined what happens from outer river plumes into the ocean. But a major “blindspot” exists – what happens between that last gauging station, and where oceanography ships pick up the signal out to sea?

The broad objective of TROCAS is to understand how water and carbon are transported through the last 900 km of the Amazon River, taking into account the multiple sources for water inputs and exchanges, tidal effects, and the geomorphology of the region. We developed a sophisticated river boat-laboratory, the B/M Mirage, to conduct a set of dedicated cruises over the lower Amazon, between 2014 and 2017 (Figure).  The first cruise, April-May 2014, coincided with historic high flow of the Amazon, where we captured the highest freshwater discharge to the ocean ever directly measured (335,000 m3/s). A critical aspect of TROCAS were the partnerships between the University of Washington and Brazilian universities, and   between NSF and Brazilian funding agencies.    

First off, we found that outgassing rates were higher than previously reported upstream, over a much broader area, likely due to the generally windier conditions, turbulence caused by tidal forces, and an amplification of these factors in the wider channels with a longer fetch. We estimated that Amazon running waters outgas as much as 1.39 Pg C year−1, or nearly three times our original estimates, increasing the global emissions from inland waters by ~43%, for a total of 2.9 Pg C year−1.   These results highlight a large missing gap in basin-scale carbon budgets along the complete continuum of the Amazon River, and likely most other large river systems.  The massive surface area of the lower Amazon River and the near-shore plume have not been adequately incorporated in global carbon budgets.

These magnitudes of fluxes raise the critical ecological question --- what produces and maintains such high levels of gases? In situ respiration has to be a major driver, but what is its true magnitude, and what supports it?  We address several long-standing assumptions that have created a perplexing paradox—historic estimates of ecosystem respiration are far too low to account for the immense CO2 outgassing from rivers. Likewise, it has long been assumed that primary production does not occur at significant rates in the Amazon mainstem. Using a novel rotating incubation system that replicates river flow velocity, we showed that in situ respiration rates can be an order of magnitude higher than traditional estimates based on stationary BOD-type bottles These new results effectively close the carbon budget for the lower Amazon River, with major implications for measurements of metabolism of freshwater. That the traditional techniques for measuring respiration may be low by several-fold suggests a significant adjustment on how the freshwater community approaches such measurements.

The next problem is, what is being respired? We estimate that the net rate of degradation observed corresponds to 30–50% of bulk river respiration. Assuming that a significant fraction of these compounds is eventually remineralized to carbon dioxide, we suggest that lignin and other terrestrially derived macromolecules contribute significantly to CO2 from inland waters. These results illustrate that the abundance and composition of OM continue to evolve along the lower reaches of large tropical rivers, which has significant implications on estimations of geochemical fluxes to the ocean.

Overall, we argue that the carbon budget of the Amazon, or any large-scale watershed, should include a systematic evaluation of the lower reaches and the near-shore marine receiving waters. We anticipate that providing greater insight into both the magnitudes of outgassing and the processes governing those fluxes in the lower reaches of major rivers and their transition to the sea will have a major impact on the understanding of how fluvial carbon cycles function, and ultimately their influence on global cycles.
